column1: #Text=# SGDLibrary : Stochastic Optimization Algorithm Library in MATLAB/Octave
#Text=Latest library version: 1.0.20 (see Release notes for more info)
#Text=We are very welcome to your contribution.
#Text=- Stochastic optimization solvers written by MATLAB, and
#Text=The SGDLibrary is a **pure-MATLAB** library or toolbox of a collection of **stochastic optimization algorithms**.
#Text=This solves an unconstrained minimization problem of the form, min f(x) = sum_i f_i(x).
#Text=The SGDLibrary is also operable on [GNU Octave](https://www.gnu.org/software/octave/) (Free software compatible with many MATLAB scripts).
#Text=Note that this SGDLibrary internally contains the [GDLibrary](https://github.com/hiroyuki-kasai/GDLibrary).
#Text=The document of SGDLibrary can be obtained from below;

#Text=Kasai, "[SGDLibrary: A MATLAB library for stochastic optimization algorithms](http://www.jmlr.org/papers/v18/17-632.html)," Journal of Machine Learning Research (JMLR), vol.18, no.215, 2018 (arXiv preprint [arXiv:1710.10951](https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.10951)).
#Text=## List of the algorithms available in SGDLibrary
#Text=Monro, "[A stochastic approximation method](https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/2236626.pdf)," The annals of mathematical statistics, vol. 22, no. 3, pp. 400-407, 1951
#Text=Bottou, "[Online learning and stochastic approximations](http://leon.bottou.org/publications/pdf/online-1998.pdf)," Edited by David Saad, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK, 1998
#Text=    - SGD-CM-NAG (SGD with classical momentum and Nesterov's Accelerated Gradient)
#Text=Hinton, "[On the importance of initialization and momentum in deep learning](https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?

#Text=|Algorithm name in example codes| function | `options.sub_mode` | other `options` |
#Text=- Note that other algorithms could be configurable by selecting other combinations of sub_mode and options.
#Text=    - Note that softmax classification problem does not support Hessian-vector product type algorithms, i.e., SQN, SVRG-SQN and SVRG-LBFGS.
#Text=Additionally, the following problems are provided for gradient descent algorithms
#Text=/run_me_first.m        - The scipt that you need to run first.
#Text=/demo.m                - Demonstration script to check and understand this package easily.
#Text=|plotter/               - Contains plotting tools to show convergence results and various plots.
#Text=|tool/                  - Some auxiliary tools for this project.
#Text=|problem/               - Problem definition files to be solved.
#Text=|sgd_test/              - Some helpful test scripts to use this package.
#Text=|gd_solver/             - Contains various gradient descent optimization algorithms.
#Text=|gd_test/               - Some helpful test scripts using gradient descent algorithms to use this package.
#Text=Just execute `demo` for the simplest demonstration of this package.
#Text=This is the case of logistic regression problem.
#Text=%% display cost/optimality gap vs number of gradient evaluations
#Text=Let take a closer look at the code above bit by bit.
#Text=First, we generate datasets including train set and test set using a data generator function `logistic_regression_data_generator()`.
#Text=The output include train set and test set and an initial value of the solution `w`.
#Text=The problem to be solved should be defined properly from the [supported problems](#supp_pro).
#Text=This returns the cost value by `cost(w)`, the gradient by `grad(w)` and the hessian by `hess(w)` when given `w`.
#Text=These are essential for any gradient descent algorithms.
#Text=Now, you can perform optimization solvers, i.e., SGD and SVRG, calling [solver functions](#supp_solver), i.e., `sgd()` function and `svrg()` function after setting some optimization options.
#Text=They return the final solutions of `w` and the statistics information that include the histories of epoch numbers, cost values, norms of gradient, the number of gradient evaluations and so on.
#Text=Finally, `display_graph()` provides output results of decreasing behavior of the cost values in terms of the number of gradient evaluations.
#Text=Note that each algorithm needs different number of evaluations of samples in each epoch.
#Text=Therefore, it is common to use this number to evaluate stochastic optimization algorithms instead of the number of iterations.
#Text=For the calculation of "optimality gap", you need optimal solution `w_opt` beforehand by calling `calc_solution()` function of the problem definition function.
#Text=%% calculate optimal solution for optimality gap
#Text=This case uses the full gradient descent solve `gd()` to obtain an optimal solution under max iteration 1000 with very precise tolerant stopping condition.
#Text=Then, you obtain the result of optimality gap by `display_graph()`.

#Text=Additionally, in this case of logistic regression, the results of classification accuracy are calculated using the corresponding prediction function `prediction()` and `accuracy` of the problem definition function `logistic_regression()`.
#Text=Furthermore, the classification accuracies are illustrated by `display_classification_result()` function that is written in "**demo.m**" like below;
#Text=display_classification_result(problem, {'SGD', 'SVRG'}, {w_sgd, w_svrg}, {y_pred_sgd, y_pred_svrg}, {accuracy_sgd, accuracy_svrg}, data.x_train, data.y_train, data.x_test, data.y_test);
#Text=You need specify additional options before executing solvers.
#Text=Note that `draw_convergence_animation()` is executable when only the dimension of the parameters is 2.
#Text=**"test_convergence_animation_demo.m"** provides you an animation of convergence behaviors of algorithms.
#Text=Please click the image below to see its animation.
#Text=- The code provided iin SGDLibrary should only be used for **academic/research purposes**.
#Text=- The codes provided by original papers are included.
#Text=- The codes ported from original python codes are included.
#Text=- scr.m, cr_subsolver.m, subsamp_tr.m, tr_subsolver.m: Python codes are originally created by [J.
#Text=These MATLAB codes are ported with original authors' big helps.
#Text=- subsamp_newton.m: originally created by Peng Xu and Jiyan Yang  in [Subsampled-Newton](https://github.com/git-xp/Subsampled-Newton).
#Text=This is modifided to handle other problems like linear regression
#Text=- As always, parameters such as the step size should be configured properly in each algorithm and each problem
#Text=- Softmax classification problem does not support "Hessian-vector product" type algorithms, i.e., SQN, SVRG-SQN and SVRG-LBFGS.
#Text=If you have any problems or questions, please contact the author: [Hiroyuki Kasai](http://kasai.comm.waseda.ac.jp/kasai/) (email: hiroyuki **dot** kasai **at** waseda **dot** jp)
